title: Good, helpful, and no longer the need to painfully type onscreen!
comment: This app makes typing much easier and quicker, the setup procedure is simple and is done with quickly, and this is reasonably secure in the way that one must have activated the input method prior to it being able to be used. Once connected, the app works flawlessly - or at least so far, it has done so. The only thing I don't like about this app are the permissions it needs, primarily the one requesting recording of keystrokes and its ability to store passwords and other sensitive information typed in. I suppose that's essential for an input method application to some extent, but this can provide a bit of a security risk which is why I use the stock keyboard when typing in such information and make sure to have the Wi-Fi turned off. I don't know how much that prevents such information being stored, but its the best I can do, and this could be a problem for the security-concerned users. But for me, its better than I hoped for.  I'd rate it a 3.8 out of 5

title: Useful for heavy texters
comment: I'm using this mainly for Whatsapp messaging and it does what is says with very little lag. Yes, you still have to go back to the phone to enter emoticons, but it still saves a lot of time when you have lots of text to enter. You can navigate around a bit with Esc, Enter, and the cursor buttons, and it also supports copy & paste, so moving text over from your computer is a breeze (saved me the detour via Evernote or Dropbox). There are other possibilities to text from your computer (namely Airdroid), but these are limited to the SMS app. This keyboard is app agnostic and I'm using it daily now. Only downside is that it seems it has introduced a lag when changing the keyboard back to Swype, etc. It takes about a minute or so until the input selection appears now once I have ended the app. Can this bug be fixed?

title: Using with Logitech Revue
comment: Just realized that I could use the Chrome browser on my Revue System, and connect to WIFI Keyboard on my EVO or Hero.  My Revue is hooked up to my HDTV at home.  So, I can get the app working, using the Revue keyboard to type on my EVO, and switch inputs on the TV so that I can watch television, while I continue to type via Revue.  *I can use Exchange email on the phone, that's not available via the Revue.  There is no reason for a keyboard to be connected to the Internet, with a unique IP address assigned to it. (Without it being connected to a PC.)  There has never been a reason to even think that.  But if that were possible, an app could connect with that specific keyboard.  If printers can have a network card, can't other devices?  I work in the IT department of a small university.  I am always looking for a cheap way to provide students with the ability to take notes (digitally) in a classroom setting.  It would be nice if they could just plop their smart devices down, connect easily to a full-sized keyboard (which IT provides), and start taking notes.  *It doesn't necessarily make sense to have to have one PC/laptop for each keyboard (although that is how it is currently).
